page.title: 04STONEWALLING IN DUFTON
page.content: Says the youthful twice winner of Dufton Show walling competition,"I have been building walls since the age of 10.On the family farm most walling is repairing gaps which appear due to old age,shifting foundations or heavy snow.Two types of stone are used_sand- stone from a local quarry & limestone from the fells.A good foundation, 2\feet wide,is dug out & 2 level rows of large stones form the base,infilled with tightly packed small stones.The walling stones cross the joints of the row below & at 2'& 4' through bands (long stones)are used.The wall is tapered towards the top & is levelled at 5',then covered by a single row of large coping stones.Walls are valued for the shelter they provide, especially for the sheep,but few new ones are built today as it is a labour intensive job & therefore expensive.
